name: Save the Cat
description: Blake Snyder's 15-beat structure for commercial storytelling
distribution_philosophy: Based on Blake Snyder's page timing for a 110-page screenplay, with major development in Fun & Games and Finale

opening_image.name: Opening Image
opening_image.description: A visual that represents the struggle and tone of the story

theme_stated.name: Theme Stated
theme_stated.description: During the setup, someone asks a question or makes a statement that is the theme

setup.name: Set-Up
setup.description: Introduce the hero, the stakes, and the goal of the story

catalyst.name: Catalyst
catalyst.description: The inciting incident that sets the story in motion

debate.name: Debate
debate.description: The hero weighs whether to take on the challenge

break_into_two.name: Break Into Two
break_into_two.description: The hero decides to take on the challenge and enters Act 2

b_story.name: B Story
b_story.description: A subplot that carries the theme of the movie

fun_and_games.name: Fun and Games
fun_and_games.description: The premise of the movie is explored - the trailer moments

midpoint.name: Midpoint
midpoint.description: An up or down moment that changes the direction of the story

bad_guys_close_in.name: Bad Guys Close In
bad_guys_close_in.description: Forces of antagonism gather momentum against the hero

all_is_lost.name: All Is Lost
all_is_lost.description: The hero's lowest point - the moment of greatest despair

dark_night_of_soul.name: Dark Night of the Soul
dark_night_of_soul.description: The hero mourns the loss and processes the journey so far

break_into_three.name: Break Into Three
break_into_three.description: The hero finds the solution to the problem

finale.name: Finale
finale.description: The hero applies the new lesson and defeats the antagonist

final_image.name: Final Image
final_image.description: A visual that represents the change that has occurred
